title: My Lab Journal
text: This is a template example for lab journaling. Students in the data science courses at the Institute of Entrepreneurship will use this template to learn R for business analytics. Students can replace this text as they wish.

title: My Lab Journal
text:
How to use

Accept the assignment and get your own github repo.
Blog/journal what you are doing in R, by editing the .qmd files.
See the links page for lots of helpful links on learning R.
Change everything to make it your own.
Make sure to render you website every time before you want to upload changes.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
expected_value_income <- mean(random_vars$income)
expected_value_age <- mean(random_vars$age)

sd_income <- sd(random_vars$income)
sd_age <- sd(random_vars$age)

var_income <- var(random_vars$income)
var_age <- var(random_vars$age)

cat("Expected Value (Income):", expected_value_income, "\n")

#> Expected Value (Income): 3510.731

cat("Expected Value (Age):", expected_value_age, "\n\n")

#> Expected Value (Age): 33.471

cat("Standard Deviation (Income):", sd_income, "\n")

#> Standard Deviation (Income): 2936.945

cat("Standard Deviation (Age):", sd_age, "\n\n")

#> Standard Deviation (Age): 18.45556

cat("Variance (Income):", var_income, "\n")

#> Variance (Income): 8625646

cat("Variance (Age):", var_age, "\n")

#> Variance (Age): 340.6078

title: Causality
text:
library(tidyverse)

year <- 2000:2009
# *3-6.2
data_divorce <- c(4.97, 4.68, 4.62, 4.45, 4.32, 4.14, 4.2, 4.2, 4.2, 3.1)
data_margarine <- c(8.2, 7, 6.5, 5.3, 5.3, 4, 4.6, 4.5, 4.2, 3.7)/2.8+1.9

data <- data.frame(year, data_divorce, data_margarine)

limits = c(3.96, 5)
limits = c(2, 9)

ggplot(data, aes(x = year)) +
  geom_line(aes(y = data_divorce), color = "red", linetype = "solid", linewidth = 1) +
  geom_line(aes(y = data_margarine), color = "black", linetype = "solid", linewidth = 1) +
  scale_y_continuous(name = "Divorce rate in Maine\nper 1000", sec.axis = sec_axis(~.*2.8-1.9, name = "Per capita consumption of margarine\nlbs")) +
  labs(title = "Divorce rate in Maine \ncorrelates with \nPer capita consumption of margarine", x = "year")

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)
library(MatchIt)

df <- readRDS("./Causal_Data_Science_Data/membership.rds")

# head(df)
# glimpse(df)

# look at correlation between parameters
print(cor(df))

#>                      age          sex pre_avg_purch        card   avg_purch
#> age           1.00000000  0.012532675   0.517506430 0.105533628 0.448632638
#> sex           0.01253267  1.000000000  -0.001221386 0.008468092 0.002181853
#> pre_avg_purch 0.51750643 -0.001221386   1.000000000 0.192333327 0.855828507
#> card          0.10553363  0.008468092   0.192333327 1.000000000 0.382352233
#> avg_purch     0.44863264  0.002181853   0.855828507 0.382352233 1.000000000

# -> looks like sex is irelevant


dag <- dagify(
  pre_avg_purch ~ age,
  pre_avg_purch ~ card,
  avg_purch ~ age,
  avg_purch ~ card,
  avg_purch ~ pre_avg_purch,
  card ~ age,
  coords = list(x = c(age = 1, card = 2, pre_avg_purch = 1, avg_purch = 2),
                y = c(age = 2, card = 2, pre_avg_purch = 1, avg_purch = 1))
)

# Plot DAG
ggdag(dag, text = F) +
  geom_dag_point(color = "blue") +
  geom_dag_text(color = NA) +
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "black") +
  geom_dag_label_repel(aes(label = name))

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)


dag <- dagify(
  parking_spots ~ location,
  sales ~ location,
  sales ~ parking_spots,
  coords = list(x = c(parking_spots = 1, location = 2, sales = 3),
                y = c(parking_spots = 1, location = 2, sales = 1))
)

# Plot DAG
ggdag(dag, text = F) +
  geom_dag_point(color = "blue") +
  geom_dag_text(color = NA) +
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "black") +
  geom_dag_label_repel(aes(label = name))

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)

df <- readRDS("./Causal_Data_Science_Data/abtest_online.rds")

# head(df)
# glimpse(df)


ggplot(df, 
       aes(x = chatbot, 
           y = previous_visit, 
           color = as.factor(chatbot))) +
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "previous_visit", title = "Difference in previous visits")







ggplot(df, 
       aes(x = chatbot, 
           y = mobile_device, 
           color = as.factor(chatbot))) +
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "mobile_device", title = "Difference in mobile devices")







ggplot(df, 
       aes(x = chatbot, 
           y = purchase_amount, 
           color = as.factor(chatbot))) +
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "purchase_amount", title = "Difference in outcome")

Note

title: Probability Theory 1
text:
1 Assignment 1

p_ts <- 0.3*0.2
p_tsn <- 0.6*0.7
p_tns <- 0.3*0.8
p_tnsn <- 0.7*0.4

print(p_ts)

#> [1] 0.06

print(p_tsn)

#> [1] 0.42

print(p_tns)

#> [1] 0.24

print(p_tnsn)

#> [1] 0.28

print(p_ts + p_tsn + p_tns + p_tnsn)

#> [1] 1




2 Assignment 2

p_3 <- 0.5 / 100
p_2m <- (7.3 + 0.5 + 3.3 + 8.8) / 100
p_1 <- 1 - p_2m

print(p_3)

#> [1] 0.005

print(p_2m)

#> [1] 0.199

print(p_1)

#> [1] 0.801




3 Assignment 3

p_bifa <- 0.97
p_bifan <- 0.01
p_a <- 0.04

p_b <- p_bifa * p_a + p_bifan * (1-p_a)
p_anifb <- p_bifan * (1-p_a) / p_b    # 0.2
p_aifb <- p_bifa * p_a / p_b          # 0.8

cat(paste("These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about ", (p_anifb *100), "% that the product is flawless and a probability of ", (p_aifb *100),"% that the product is faulty."))

#> These results show that in case the alarm is triggered, there is a possibility of about  19.8347107438017 % that the product is flawless and a probability of  80.1652892561983 % that the product is faulty.

title: Statistical Concepts
text:
expected_value_income <- mean(random_vars$income)
expected_value_age <- mean(random_vars$age)

sd_income <- sd(random_vars$income)
sd_age <- sd(random_vars$age)

var_income <- var(random_vars$income)
var_age <- var(random_vars$age)

cat("Expected Value (Income):", expected_value_income, "\n")

#> Expected Value (Income): 3510.731

cat("Expected Value (Age):", expected_value_age, "\n\n")

#> Expected Value (Age): 33.471

cat("Standard Deviation (Income):", sd_income, "\n")

#> Standard Deviation (Income): 2936.945

cat("Standard Deviation (Age):", sd_age, "\n\n")

#> Standard Deviation (Age): 18.45556

cat("Variance (Income):", var_income, "\n")

#> Variance (Income): 8625646

cat("Variance (Age):", var_age, "\n")

#> Variance (Age): 340.6078

title: Statistical Concepts
section: 2 Explain, if it makes sense to compare the standard deviations.
text:
2 Explain, if it makes sense to compare the standard deviations.
No, because the units are different.

title: Statistical Concepts
section: 3 Then, examine the relationship between both variables and compute:
text:
3 Then, examine the relationship between both variables and compute:

covariance <- cov(random_vars)
correlation <- cor(random_vars)

cat("Covariance:", covariance[1,2], "\n")

#> Covariance: 29700.15

cat("Correlation:", correlation[1,2], "\n")

#> Correlation: 0.5479432

title: Statistical Concepts
section: 4 What measure is easier to interpret? Please discuss your interpretation.
text:
4 What measure is easier to interpret? Please discuss your interpretation.
Correlation is better to interpret, because it is defined between [-1, 1] and therefore unit less. That means, e.g. if the correlation goes against 1, it approaches the maximum. This cannot be seen with covariance.

title: Statistical Concepts
section: 5 Compute the conditional expected value for:
text:
5 Compute the conditional expected value for:

expected_value_income_under18 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age<=18])
expected_value_income_18to65 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age>18 & random_vars$age<65])
expected_value_income_over65 <- mean(random_vars$income[random_vars$age>=65])

cat("Expected Income under 18:", expected_value_income_under18, "\n")

#> Expected Income under 18: 389.6074

cat("Expected Income between 18 and 65:", expected_value_income_18to65, "\n")

#> Expected Income between 18 and 65: 4737.609

cat("Expected Income over 65:", expected_value_income_over65, "\n")

#> Expected Income over 65: 1777.237

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
4 Regressor example
The regressor ‘enginesize’ takes on continual data ranging from 61 to 326, as can be seen in the glimpse. The slope is 125.934 meaning if we increase the enginesize by 1, the price increases by 125.934. It is statistically relevant because the p-value is 5e-06 which is less than 0.05 (our assumed alpha).

title: Regression and Statistical Inference
text:
5 Adding new variable

df$seat_heating <- TRUE

lm_all <- lm(price ~ ., data = df)
summary(lm_all)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = price ~ ., data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>    Min     1Q Median     3Q    Max 
#>  -5662  -1120      0    798   9040 
#> 
#> Coefficients: (1 not defined because of singularities)

#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2189 on 143 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9415, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9264 
#> F-statistic: 62.21 on 37 and 143 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16


The model recognized that all observations for this new regressor are the same and therefore do not influence the resulting price. The coefficients are not available (NA) and therefore not included in the model.

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)


dag <- dagify(
  parking_spots ~ location,
  sales ~ location,
  sales ~ parking_spots,
  coords = list(x = c(parking_spots = 1, location = 2, sales = 3),
                y = c(parking_spots = 1, location = 2, sales = 1))
)

# Plot DAG
ggdag(dag, text = F) +
  geom_dag_point(color = "blue") +
  geom_dag_text(color = NA) +
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "black") +
  geom_dag_label_repel(aes(label = name))

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
2 Regression models

df <- readRDS("./Causal_Data_Science_Data/customer_sat.rds")

lm <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df)
summary(lm)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -12.412  -5.257   1.733   4.506  12.588 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  78.8860     4.2717  18.467 1.04e-10 ***
#> follow_ups   -3.3093     0.6618  -5.001 0.000243 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 7.923 on 13 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.658,  Adjusted R-squared:  0.6316 
#> F-statistic: 25.01 on 1 and 13 DF,  p-value: 0.0002427

lm_all <- lm(satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = df)
summary(lm_all)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = satisfaction ~ follow_ups + subscription, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -4.3222 -2.1972  0.3167  2.2667  3.9944 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                      Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)           26.7667     6.6804   4.007  0.00206 ** 
#> follow_ups             2.1944     0.7795   2.815  0.01682 *  
#> subscriptionPremium   44.7222     5.6213   7.956 6.88e-06 ***
#> subscriptionPremium+  18.0722     2.1659   8.344 4.37e-06 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 2.958 on 11 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.9597, Adjusted R-squared:  0.9487 
#> F-statistic: 87.21 on 3 and 11 DF,  p-value: 5.956e-08

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
3 Explanation
In the first model the coefficient for follow ups is -3.3, which means that for every follow up call the satisfaction goes down. In the second model the coefficient is 2.19, meaning the satisfaction goes up 2.19 points per follow up. This makes more sense, as a follow up call is unlikely to decrease customer satisfaction. The reason for this is, that model 2 also takes subscriptions into account.

title: Directed Acyclic Graphs
text:
4 Plot data

data_not_cond <- ggplot(df, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction)) +
  geom_point(alpha = .8) +
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F)

data_not_cond

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'










# Conditioning on subscription  
data_cond <- ggplot(df, aes(x = follow_ups, y = satisfaction, color = subscription)) +
  geom_point(alpha = .8) +
  stat_smooth(method = "lm", se = F) +
  theme(legend.position = "right")

data_cond

#> `geom_smooth()` using formula = 'y ~ x'

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)

df <- readRDS("./Causal_Data_Science_Data/abtest_online.rds")

# head(df)
# glimpse(df)


ggplot(df, 
       aes(x = chatbot, 
           y = previous_visit, 
           color = as.factor(chatbot))) +
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "previous_visit", title = "Difference in previous visits")







ggplot(df, 
       aes(x = chatbot, 
           y = mobile_device, 
           color = as.factor(chatbot))) +
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "mobile_device", title = "Difference in mobile devices")







ggplot(df, 
       aes(x = chatbot, 
           y = purchase_amount, 
           color = as.factor(chatbot))) +
  stat_summary(geom = "errorbar", 
               width = .5,
               fun.data = "mean_se", 
               fun.args = list(mult=1.96),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = NULL, y = "purchase_amount", title = "Difference in outcome")

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
2 Regression model

lm <- lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, data = df)
summary(lm)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, 
#>     data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -25.414 -14.428  -8.435  12.559  64.584 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                   Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)        15.2840     1.1227  13.614  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE        -6.8488     1.1792  -5.808 8.49e-09 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE  -0.8562     1.2642  -0.677  0.49841    
#> previous_visit      0.7792     0.2869   2.716  0.00673 ** 
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.6 on 996 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.04243,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03954 
#> F-statistic: 14.71 on 3 and 996 DF,  p-value: 2.228e-09

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
section: 3 Sub-group regression model for mobile devices
text:
3 Sub-group regression model for mobile devices

lm_sub <- lm(purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device + previous_visit, data = df)
summary(lm_sub)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = purchase_amount ~ chatbot * mobile_device + previous_visit, 
#>     data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
#> -25.403 -14.450  -8.445  12.549  64.562 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                               Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)                   15.27384    1.19130  12.821  < 2e-16 ***
#> chatbotTRUE                   -6.82837    1.42580  -4.789 1.93e-06 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE             -0.82375    1.79309  -0.459  0.64605    
#> previous_visit                 0.77914    0.28711   2.714  0.00677 ** 
#> chatbotTRUE:mobile_deviceTRUE -0.06455    2.52907  -0.026  0.97964    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 18.6 on 995 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.04243,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.03858 
#> F-statistic: 11.02 on 4 and 995 DF,  p-value: 9.485e-09

title: Randomized Controlled Trials
text:
4 Logistic regression model

lm_log <- glm(purchase ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, data = df, family = "binomial")
summary(lm_log)

#> 
#> Call:
#> glm(formula = purchase ~ chatbot + mobile_device + previous_visit, 
#>     family = "binomial", data = df)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                   Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
#> (Intercept)       -0.22185    0.12347  -1.797  0.07237 .  
#> chatbotTRUE       -0.96894    0.13564  -7.144 9.09e-13 ***
#> mobile_deviceTRUE -0.07119    0.14530  -0.490  0.62417    
#> previous_visit     0.10606    0.03262   3.252  0.00115 ** 
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
#> 
#>     Null deviance: 1329.1  on 999  degrees of freedom
#> Residual deviance: 1262.2  on 996  degrees of freedom
#> AIC: 1270.2
#> 
#> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4


The coefficients in logistical regression are log-odds. That means we have to exponentiate them to get the real odds. In this case exp(-0.969) = 0.38. Therefore, if chatbot is true, the odds are 38% higher that something is bought.

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(dagitty)
library(ggdag)
library(MatchIt)

df <- readRDS("./Causal_Data_Science_Data/membership.rds")

# head(df)
# glimpse(df)

# look at correlation between parameters
print(cor(df))

#>                      age          sex pre_avg_purch        card   avg_purch
#> age           1.00000000  0.012532675   0.517506430 0.105533628 0.448632638
#> sex           0.01253267  1.000000000  -0.001221386 0.008468092 0.002181853
#> pre_avg_purch 0.51750643 -0.001221386   1.000000000 0.192333327 0.855828507
#> card          0.10553363  0.008468092   0.192333327 1.000000000 0.382352233
#> avg_purch     0.44863264  0.002181853   0.855828507 0.382352233 1.000000000

# -> looks like sex is irelevant


dag <- dagify(
  pre_avg_purch ~ age,
  pre_avg_purch ~ card,
  avg_purch ~ age,
  avg_purch ~ card,
  avg_purch ~ pre_avg_purch,
  card ~ age,
  coords = list(x = c(age = 1, card = 2, pre_avg_purch = 1, avg_purch = 2),
                y = c(age = 2, card = 2, pre_avg_purch = 1, avg_purch = 1))
)

# Plot DAG
ggdag(dag, text = F) +
  geom_dag_point(color = "blue") +
  geom_dag_text(color = NA) +
  geom_dag_edges(edge_color = "black") +
  geom_dag_label_repel(aes(label = name))

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
2 Naive estimate

# Naive estimate of the ATE
model_naive <- lm(avg_purch ~ card, data = df)
summary(model_naive)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df)
#> 
#> Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -101.515  -20.684   -0.199   20.424  120.166 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  65.9397     0.3965  166.29   <2e-16 ***
#> card         25.2195     0.6095   41.38   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 30.11 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.1462, Adjusted R-squared:  0.1461 
#> F-statistic:  1712 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16

title: Matching and Subclassification
text:
3 Matching

CEM

# CEM estimation
cem <- matchit(card ~ age + pre_avg_purch + sex,
               data = df, 
               method = 'cem', 
               estimand = 'ATE')

summary(cem)

#> 
#> Call:
#> matchit(formula = card ~ age + pre_avg_purch + sex, data = df, 
#>     method = "cem", estimand = "ATE")
#> 
#> Summary of Balance for All Data:
#>               Means Treated Means Control Std. Mean Diff. Var. Ratio eCDF Mean
#> age                 42.0331       39.1574          0.2136     1.1524    0.0438
#> pre_avg_purch       76.3938       66.0438          0.3962     1.0276    0.1092
#> sex                  0.5087        0.5002          0.0171          .    0.0086
#>               eCDF Max
#> age             0.0864
#> pre_avg_purch   0.1545
#> sex             0.0086
#> 
#> Summary of Balance for Matched Data:
#>               Means Treated Means Control Std. Mean Diff. Var. Ratio eCDF Mean
#> age                 40.1743       40.1557          0.0014     0.9993    0.0016
#> pre_avg_purch       70.4611       70.0938          0.0141     0.9929    0.0044
#> sex                  0.5040        0.5040          0.0000          .    0.0000
#>               eCDF Max Std. Pair Dist.
#> age             0.0064          0.1222
#> pre_avg_purch   0.0130          0.1558
#> sex             0.0000          0.0000
#> 
#> Sample Sizes:
#>               Control Treated
#> All           5768.      4232
#> Matched (ESS) 5429.65    3844
#> Matched       5716.      4164
#> Unmatched       52.        68
#> Discarded        0.         0

df_cem <- match.data(cem)

model_cem <- lm(avg_purch ~ card, data = df_cem, weights = weights)
summary(model_cem)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_cem, weights = weights)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -159.349  -20.459   -0.151   19.863  161.528 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  69.9896     0.3984  175.66   <2e-16 ***
#> card         15.2043     0.6137   24.77   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 30.12 on 9878 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.0585, Adjusted R-squared:  0.0584 
#> F-statistic: 613.7 on 1 and 9878 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16




Nearest neighbnour

# Nearest Neighbour
nn <- matchit(card ~ age + pre_avg_purch + sex,
               data = df, 
               method = "nearest", 
               distance = "mahalanobis",
               replace = T)

summary(nn)

#> 
#> Call:
#> matchit(formula = card ~ age + pre_avg_purch + sex, data = df, 
#>     method = "nearest", distance = "mahalanobis", replace = T)
#> 
#> Summary of Balance for All Data:
#>               Means Treated Means Control Std. Mean Diff. Var. Ratio eCDF Mean
#> age                 42.0331       39.1574          0.2064     1.1524    0.0438
#> pre_avg_purch       76.3938       66.0438          0.3936     1.0276    0.1092
#> sex                  0.5087        0.5002          0.0171          .    0.0086
#>               eCDF Max
#> age             0.0864
#> pre_avg_purch   0.1545
#> sex             0.0086
#> 
#> Summary of Balance for Matched Data:
#>               Means Treated Means Control Std. Mean Diff. Var. Ratio eCDF Mean
#> age                 42.0331       41.9964          0.0026     1.0171    0.0014
#> pre_avg_purch       76.3938       76.2937          0.0038     1.0178    0.0012
#> sex                  0.5087        0.5087          0.0000          .    0.0000
#>               eCDF Max Std. Pair Dist.
#> age             0.0061          0.0281
#> pre_avg_purch   0.0076          0.0301
#> sex             0.0000          0.0000
#> 
#> Sample Sizes:
#>               Control Treated
#> All           5768.      4232
#> Matched (ESS) 1992.19    4232
#> Matched       2677.      4232
#> Unmatched     3091.         0
#> Discarded        0.         0

df_nn <- match.data(nn)

model_nn <- lm(avg_purch ~ card, data = df_nn, weights = weights)
summary(model_nn)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_nn, weights = weights)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -132.730  -21.288   -1.675   18.318  146.631 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  76.5634     0.5881  130.19   <2e-16 ***
#> card         14.5957     0.7514   19.42   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 30.43 on 6907 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.05179,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.05166 
#> F-statistic: 377.3 on 1 and 6907 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16




Inverse Probability Weighting

# Propensity scores
model_prop <- glm(card ~ age + pre_avg_purch + sex,
                  data = df,
                  family = binomial(link = "logit"))
summary(model_prop)

#> 
#> Call:
#> glm(formula = card ~ age + pre_avg_purch + sex, family = binomial(link = "logit"), 
#>     data = df)
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>                 Estimate Std. Error z value Pr(>|z|)    
#> (Intercept)   -1.4298676  0.0752043 -19.013   <2e-16 ***
#> age            0.0011486  0.0017761   0.647    0.518    
#> pre_avg_purch  0.0148262  0.0009264  16.003   <2e-16 ***
#> sex            0.0359388  0.0412622   0.871    0.384    
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> (Dispersion parameter for binomial family taken to be 1)
#> 
#>     Null deviance: 13626  on 9999  degrees of freedom
#> Residual deviance: 13249  on 9996  degrees of freedom
#> AIC: 13257
#> 
#> Number of Fisher Scoring iterations: 4

df_aug <- df %>% mutate(propensity = predict(model_prop, type = "response"))

df_ipw <- df_aug %>% mutate(
  ipw = (card/propensity) + ((1-card) / (1-propensity)))

df_ipw %>% 
  select(card, age, sex, pre_avg_purch, propensity, ipw)



  


model_ipw <- lm(avg_purch ~ card,
                data = df_ipw, 
                weights = ipw)
summary(model_ipw)

#> 
#> Call:
#> lm(formula = avg_purch ~ card, data = df_ipw, weights = ipw)
#> 
#> Weighted Residuals:
#>      Min       1Q   Median       3Q      Max 
#> -205.353  -28.995   -0.275   28.787  214.307 
#> 
#> Coefficients:
#>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
#> (Intercept)  70.2628     0.4320  162.66   <2e-16 ***
#> card         14.9573     0.6109   24.48   <2e-16 ***
#> ---
#> Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1
#> 
#> Residual standard error: 43.19 on 9998 degrees of freedom
#> Multiple R-squared:  0.05657,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.05647 
#> F-statistic: 599.5 on 1 and 9998 DF,  p-value: < 2.2e-16




Summary

# Summary of naive and matching methods
modelsummary::modelsummary(list("Naive" = model_naive,
                                "CEM1"  = model_cem,
                                "NN"    = model_nn,
                                "IPW1"  = model_ipw))
